resource.chars:
two sets cross and produce the branchial 
network -
The line between the monochitonida &
Dichitonida can certainly then, not be drawn 
between the Salpae & Pyrosomata -
The Pyrosomata - in the main - have the 
closest similarity in structure to the Botryllidae 
& other compound ascidians - but in these 
latter the separation between the test and 
the outer tunic becomes more and more 
marked - until it attains its greatest amount 
in the Clavelinidae, Cynthiae &c
Now <s>[text?]<\s> does this separation furnish a 
character of any value or importance, systematically?
Surely not, for the value of a character depends 
upon the number of differences of which it is 
a mark - and this is the mark of none -
Savigny observed the close resemblance between 
Botryllus and Pyrosoma - which yet differ in 
this character -
Clavelina and Perophora are acknowledged 
to be closely allied genera and yet - in the 
former the test and outer tunic are separated 
to their utmost extent - in the latter X they are 
as closely united as in any Salpa 
In the Cynthiae the test and tunics are generally 
very distinct - but in Cynthia ampulloida 
judging by the descriptions of Van Beneden they 
are compounded together - +
* See the very beautiful figures and descriptions 
of Lister in the Phil. Trans. for 1834.
Mem. de l’Acad. Roy. de Bruxelles vol
